title: Environmental Design for Behavioral Regulation in People With Dementia
description_brief: Individuals with dementia present with changes in behaviors throughout the continuum of cognitive decline. Environmental features may be influential in behavioral regulation. The purpose of this study is to assess the feasibility of environmental design protocols in older adults with dementia and their caregivers. Thirty subjects with moderate to severe Alzheimer's disease as primary dementia type, and their caregivers, will be randomly assigned to one of three arms: standard care; standard environmental design protocol; or personalized environmental design protocol.

participantFlowModule.preAssignmentDetails: Of 96 patient-caregiver dyads, 60 dyads were excluded (52 did not meet inclusion criteria; 4 declined to participate; 10 for other reasons.) Patients and their caregivers were enrolled as dyads. 30 dyads were randomized (10 to control, 10 to Standardized, 10 to Individualized) and 25 dyads completed the study.
participantFlowModule.recruitmentDetails: Individuals diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease (Clinical Dementia Rating Scale \[CDR\] score of 1.0+) living in the community with caregiver-identified behavioral disturbance were recruited from the UK Alzheimer's Disease Research Center (UK ADRC)

groups.title: Control Group
groups.description:
Alzheimer's disease patients and caregivers.

Placebo: Participants' caregivers will receive a set script of placebo modifications.

groups.title: Standard Environmental Design
groups.description:
Alzheimer's disease patients and caregivers.

Standard Environmental Design: Participants' caregivers will receive set script of physical environmental modifications (i.e., declutter living space, reduce background noise, increase natural light), and social environment training script will include caregiving techniques: training for calming demeanor (emotional contagion), needs-driven care to decrease behavioral disruption, and accepting and accommodating approach to behavioral disruption. A pre-selected sensory stimulation kit will be provided to each participants' caregiver for administration throughout the day.

groups.title: Individualized Environmental Design Protocol
groups.description:
Alzheimer's disease patients and caregivers.

Individual Environmental Design: Participants' caregivers will receive set script of physical environmental modifications and social environment training script in a standard protocol. Following initial assessments, individualized sensory stimulation kits will be developed using subjects' preferred sensory stimuli (as determined by the Adult Sensory Profile assessment and informant report) and will be provided via caregiver administration throughout the day to promote maintained behavioral regulation.

milestones.comment: All numbers in this table represent dyads. One dyad is patient and their caregiver (total participants = 2 per dyad).

outcomeMeasures.title: Success Rate of Adherence
outcomeMeasures.description: Percentage of participants who had 75% adherence to the protocol based on visits and journals.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Difference of success rates among participants

analyses.groupDescription: Primary outcome analyzed via success rates among groups.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Occupational Performance
outcomeMeasures.description: Occupational performance will be measured using the Canadian Occupational Performance Measure (COPM) at baseline, post-intervention and the 4-week follow up. Scores range from 0-10; higher scores indicate (increased) occupational performance.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: 10 weeks (at baseline, 6 weeks and the 4 week follow up)

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Behavior
outcomeMeasures.description: Behavior will be measured using the Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI-Q) at baseline, post-intervention and the 4-week follow up. Scores range from 1-36; higher scores indicate higher behavior severity.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: 10 weeks (at baseline, 6 weeks and the 4 week follow up)

explanation_target: Reason: The intervention is an environmental-design (behavioral) protocol aimed at changing the home environment and caregiver practices to regulate behavioral symptoms in people with moderate–severe Alzheimer’s disease — i.e., the trial’s intent is to reduce neuropsychiatric/behavioral symptoms rather than to modify Alzheimer pathology or provide a cognitive-enhancing drug. citeturn1search1turn1search0

Act (key details extracted): The study (NCT04555616) randomizes 30 dyads (people with moderate–severe AD and their caregivers) to control (placebo behavioral script), standard environmental design, or individualized environmental design; primary/secondary outcomes include adherence and change in behavior measured by the Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI‑Q) and occupational performance (COPM). No pharmaceutical agent or biologic is used. citeturn1search1turn1search0

Web search results supporting extraction: ClinicalTrials.gov record and registry summaries for NCT04555616 describing the trial title, arms (placebo behavioral, standard environmental design, individualized environmental design), population, and outcomes. citeturn1search1turn1search0turn1search2

Reflect: Classification rationale — this is a non‑pharmacologic, behavioral/environmental intervention targeting neuropsychiatric/behavioral symptoms (measured by NPI‑Q). It does not fit 'disease‑targeted biologic' or 'disease‑targeted small molecule' or 'cognitive enhancer'. Therefore the correct category is 'neuropsychiatric symptom improvement'. Additional supportive literature shows environmental design can influence behavioral outcomes in dementia. citeturn0search7turn0search2
explanation_agent: Reason: The intervention is an environmental‑design (behavioral) protocol intended to regulate neuropsychiatric/behavioral symptoms in people with moderate–severe Alzheimer disease rather than a drug or biologic targeting disease biology. citeturn0search0

Act: Key trial details — NCT04555616 randomizes ~30 dyads to three behavioral arms (placebo behavioral script / standard environmental design / individualized environmental design); outcomes include adherence, change in behavior (NPI‑Q) and occupational performance (COPM). No pharmaceutical agent or biologic is used. citeturn0search0turn0search2

Reflect: This is a non‑pharmacologic, symptom‑directed environmental intervention (behavioral/environmental design) that aims to reduce behavioral symptoms (BPSD/NPI) rather than modify amyloid, tau, inflammation, synaptic function, metabolism, vasculature, or other CADRO‑listed biological targets. CADRO does not include a specific category for behavioral/environmental interventions, so the correct mapping is 'T) Other'. Supporting literature shows environmental design can improve behavioral outcomes in dementia (examples: indoor therapeutic garden RCT and a meta‑review of environmental effects on behavior/quality of life). citeturn0search1turn0search3

Web search results used (key records): ClinicalTrials.gov / trial registry summary for NCT04555616 (trial details, arms, outcomes). citeturn0search0; Trial aggregator/summary pages (MedPath / PlatoHealth) echoing registry details. citeturn0search2turn0search4; Relevant evidence on environmental interventions reducing BPSD: randomized indoor therapeutic garden trial and a systematic meta‑review. citeturn0search1turn0search3
